TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract MenuBase extends System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl

Docs.summary: Represents a control that defines choices for users to select.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The MenuBase is the base class for controls that define choices for users to select. The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Menu> and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> inherit from MenuBase and allow the user to select an item to invoke some action.
MenuBase is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel). For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> class.

Docs.param: The item to check whether it is an item container.
Docs.summary: Determines whether the specified item is, or is eligible to be, its own item container.
Gets or sets the custom logic for choosing a template used to display each item.
Docs.value: A custom object that provides logic and returns an item container.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use an to choose different item containers if the items in your collection are the same type and you need to provide custom logic to choose the item container. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnKeyDown(class System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: The event data for the event.
Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when the user presses a key.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the user presses ESC, ALT+ALT, or ALT+F10, this implementation marks the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.KeyDown> event as handled by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the event data to `true`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnMouseLeave(class System.Windows.Input.MouseEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: The event data for the event.
Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when the mouse leaves the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This implementation does not change the handled state (the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property) of the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeave> event data.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the menu selects different item containers, depending on the type of the item in the underlying collection or some other heuristic.
Docs.value:
the menu selects different item containers; otherwise, .
The registered default is . For more information about what can influence the value, see [Dependency Property Value Precedence](../Topic/Dependency%20Property%20Value%20Precedence.md).

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is useful if you want to create a menu by binding to a collection. The item container is the UI element that displays the object in a collection. If you want to bind to a collection to create a menu that contains objects and objects, set the UsesItemContainerTemplate property to true and create an for each type of object in your collection. Each must contain either a or a . ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
